pr_title: Assume java.base for the module of a null caller class

timeline.bodyText: Why add the new API in VM?  Wouldn't doing Class.class.getModule() here work?
timeline.author: DanHeidinga

replies.bodyText:
Class.class.getModule() works as well. VM.getJavabaseModule() intended to cache the java.base module and avoid repetition of Class.class.getModule().
Depending on the number of calls j.l.Class.useModularSearch(), the saving might vary.
If it is not preferred to add a new API in VM,  Class.class.getModule() can be used instead.
replies.author: JasonFengJ9

replies.bodyText: getModule() is a simple getter, so it's faster than the cache code anyway. Only a final static would be faster, and that only by a few bytecodes.
replies.author: gacholio

replies.bodyText:
Agreed, PR updated.
@DanHeidinga @gacholio please have another look.
replies.author: JasonFengJ9

timeline.message:
Assume java.base for the module of a null caller class

System.getCallerClass() might return a null caller class for a caller
within a JVMTI callback function when
walkStackFrames()/cInterpGetStackClassJEP176Iterator() walked off the
end of the stack. Refer #8993 for more info;
In such case, assume java.base for the module of such callers.

Signed-off-by: Jason Feng <fengj@ca.ibm.com>
